INDEPENDENT STATE OF PAPUA NEW GUINEA
DIVUNE HYDROPOWER PROJECT

LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY

Borrower	

Beneficiaries	

The Independent State of Papua New Guinea

The Project will directly benefit about 17,000
people in and around Popondetta, the
administrative and commercial center of Oro
Province through lower cost and more reliable
power supply, and indirectly benefit about 80,000
people in the rest of the Province by stimulating
economic growth and providing the necessary
infrastructure.

:	

:	

:	

Executing Agency	

Papua New Guinea Electricity Commission (ELCOM)

Loan Amount : The equivalent in various currencies of $8.43
million from the ordinary capital resources (OCR)
of the Bank.

Ternis : 20 years, including a grace period of three years
at an Interest rate to be determined in
accordance with Bank's pool-based variable
lending rate system and a commitment charge of
0.75 per cent per annum in accordance with the
current Bank policy.

Relending Terms : The Borrower will relend the proceeds of the loan
to ELCOM as the Executing Agency under a
subsidiary loan agreement with a relending rate
set at the standard rate applicable to Commercial
Statutory Authorities (CSA) in PNG, but not less
than the OCR rate of the Bank at the time of the
approval of the loan by the Bank.

Period of Utilization:	

Until 31 December 1992

Project Description : The project will consist of the following
components: (i) construction of a hydropower
station with two units of 1.5 MW each and
associated civil works; (ii) construction of
about 85 kin of 22 kV lines for transmitting the
hydropower to the load centers in the Project
area; and (iii) consulting services for
engineering assistance during the construction
phase of the Project.

iv

Procurement
Arrangements

Recruitment of
Consultants

Procurement of goods and services to be financed
from the proceeds of the proposed Bank loan will
be carried out by the Executing Agency in
accordance with the Bank's Guidelines for
Procurement. ICB procedures will be adopted for
the civil works and electro-mechanical works
components of the Project. Because of the
estimated small contract values, IS procedures
will be applied for the transmission component.

About two man-months of consulting services will
be required for engineering assistance during the
construction phase of the Project. In the
interest of timely and economic Project
implementation, and in accordance with the Bank's
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants, it is
proposed to retain the TA Consultant, who was
responsible for the final feasibility studies and
detailed engineering of the Project, for
providing these consulting services.

Project Benefits : The Project will displace the high-cost imported
diesel-based generation with the lower cost,
indigenous, and renewable hydropower in the
Popondetta area of Oro Province and will also
improve the reliability of power supply in the
area. The EIRR of the Project is estimated at
13.8 per cent and the FIRR at about 12.7 per
cent.

Appraisal Report	

:	

No. LAP:PNG-20079

 REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION OF THE PRESIDENT
TO THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS ON A PROPOSED LOAN
TO THE INDEPENDENT STATE OF PAPUA NEW GUINEA
FOR THE DIVUNE HYDROPOWER PROJECT

1.
I submit to the Board of Directors, for its consideration and
decision, the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed loan from
the ordinary capital resources of the Bank in an amount in various
currencies equivalent to $8.43 million applied for by the Independent
State of Papua New Guinea for the Divune Hydropower Project. The proposed
loan has a term of 20 years, including a grace period of three years, at
an interest rate determined in accordance with Bank's pool-based variable
lending rate system, and a commitment charge of 0.75 per cent in
accordance with the current Bank policy.

At the request of the Government of the Independent State of
2.
Papua New Guinea (PNG), a technical assistance was provided by the Bank
in November 1986 for a feasibility study for the proposed Project. 1/ The
final report of the study was submitted to the Bank by the consultant,
Macdonald Wagner, Australia, in June 1988. After the Government confirmed
the need for the Project during the High-Level talks held in Manila in
December 1988, a Fact-Finding Mission was fielded in February 1989 to
discuss with the Government and the Executing Agency the scope of the
proposed Project as well as the financing and implementation arrangements.
From 4-12 April 1989 a Bank Appraisal Mission visited PNG and confirmed
that the Government accorded high priority to the Project and that it was
suitable for Bank financing. Formal loan negotiations with authorized
representatives of the Government and the Executing Agency were held in
Manila from 30 to 31 May 1989. If approved, the proposed loan will be
the Bank's twentyninth loan to PNG and the fifth loan for the power
subsector in the country.

I. THE ECONOMY

An Economic Survey of PNG (Report No. PNG: EC-5s) was circulated
3.
to the Board of Directors in September 1987. Also a Board Information
Paper entitled "Papua New Guinea: Economic Review and Bank Operations"
(Report No. EBO PNG 89006) was circulated in June 1989.

A.	

The Energy Sector and the Power Subsector

1.	

The Energy Sector

Situated about 160 km north of Australia and with a land area
4.
of 461,700 sq km, PNG comprises the eastern half of the New Guinea island
and about 600 offshore islands. With a population of around 3.7 million
(mid-1988), the country is sparsely inhabited with a population density
of only eight persons per sq km. PNG is a land of great geographical

1/

TA No. 823-PNG: Luwini (Divune) Hydropower, approved on 27 November
1986 in the amount of '$150,000.

	
	
 2

diversity with high mountains ) volcanoes, many rivers and low-lying
swamps. The country is marked by rugged terrain rendering a large part
of the highlands inaccessible and thereby resulting in fragmented small
population centers in the hinterlands, often completely isolated from each
other. Therefore, development of large hydropower resources has not been
viable, and so far only 189 MW, or a little over one per cent of the
abundant hydropower potential estimated at over 14,000 MW, has been
developed. Furthermore, most of the hydropower projects in operation are
run-of-the-river power stations with very little firm energy potential.

Significant oil and gas discoveries have been made in various
5.
parts of the country. PNG's hydrocarbon reserves are estimated at about
18 trillion cubic feet of gas, 167 million barrels of condensates and 270
million barrels of oil. Part of these reserves are being developed for
power generation for new gold mines as well as for export. PNG has also
a significant biotnass potential with forests covering about 33 million
hectares. Surface manifestations of geothermal energy have been observed
in several parts of the country, and coal deposits have been reported in
the Gulf and Morobe provinces, but so far no serious attempts have been
made to inventory and exploit these resources because of the anticipated
high development costs.

The energy sector of PNG has developed alongside the various
6.
enclaves, notably in the two major ones, viz. Bougainville Copper Limited
(BCL) in Bougainville island (North Solomons Province), and the Ok Tedi
Mine in the north-western part of the mainland (Western Province), which
together in 1987 accounted for about 35 per cent of the country's total
commercial energy consumption. However, both these enclaves are isolated
from the country's other major demand centers, and while most of the
population has little or no access to commercial energy, some 15 per cent
of the population in the modern sector account for about 60 per cent of
total energy consumed.

The total primary energy consumption in 1987 was estimated at
7.
about 1.6 million tons of oil equivalent. Of this, petroleum products
accounted for about 55 per cent, non-commercial fuels (mainly fuel wood)
for 37 per cent, and hydropower for eight per cent. At present, 87 per
cent of the commercial energy needs are met by oil products and the
balance of 13 per cent by hydropower generation. All oil products to date
have been imported, at a cost in 1986 of K 83.30 million, representing
more than nine per cent of the country's total imports and equivalent to
8.3 per cent of the export earnings in that year.

2.	

The Power Subsector

Electric power in the country is provided through: (i) the
8.
facilities of ELCOM, supplying electricity to most of the domestic,
commercial and industrial consumers; (ii) Government owned power supply
facilities (based mostly on small diesel generating units) in remote areas
for providing limited power supply to important rural centers ("C"
centers); and (iii) privately owned captive generating plants. Of the
about 548 NW installed generating capacity in the power subsector by the

 3

end of 1988, 200 MW (36.5 per cent) were owned by ELCOM, 8 MW (1.5 per
cent) by the Government and 340 MW (62 per cent) by the private sector.

At present, ELCOM is serving 26 urban centers through 18
9.
independent power systems, and of its total installed generating capacity
by end 1988 (200 MW), hydropower accounted for 130 MW (65 per cent),
diesel for 55 MW (27 per cent) and gas turbines for 15 MW (8 per cent).
ELCOM's transmission and distribution systems comprise 880 kin of htgh
voltage lines, about 2,000 km of medium voltage and 1,000 km of low-
voltage lines, as well as distribution transformers with a total capacity
of about 285 MVA. In 1988, ELCOM generated 555 GWh and purchased 55 GWh
from the private sector, with sales in that year totalling 547 GWb. The
system energy losses were about 10 per cent.

During the last ten years, the annual load growth averaged five
10.
per cent, with a decline in the early 1980s, mainly due to capacity
deficits in the system as well as the unreliability of power supply
because of the inadequacy of the transmission systems. This resulted in
considerable suppressed demand in ELCOM's systems and a significant
Increase in captive generation. With the Improvements In the subsequent
years, and with the planned addition to the generating capacity and
reinforcement of the transmission systems, ELCOM's energy sales are
projected to increase from 589 GWh in 1989 to 982 GWh by 1998. After an
expected load Increase in 1991 and 1992 of 12.6 per cent and 11.2 per
cent, respectively, due to the incidence of a large load (viz, the Hidden
Valley gold mine), the annual growth rate Is conservatively projected at
about 3.6 per cent over the following years. However, in view of the
still low level of consumption, the suppressed load demand and the various
development programs recently Initiated by the Government (see paras. 19-
20), this forecast might be an underestimate, particularly in the longer
time frame.

Despite supply constraints and unreliable supply due to the
11.
ageing of the existing diesel units, ELCOM's energy sales in the Project
area (Popondetta) have grown from 2.92 GWh in 1981 to 4.47 GWh in 1988.
As a result of the proposed Project, which envisages also the connection
of various settlements, a number of saw mills and other large loads, most
of which have their own captive power plants, electricity sales in the
Project area are projected to increase to 8.45 GWh in 1992, the first year
of operation of the Project. Thereafter, the sales are projected to
increase at an average rate of about 3.6 per cent per annum.

B.	

Government's Development Plan and Sectoral Strateg1

Government's most recent Development Plan (Economic Policy and
12.
Fiscal Strategy) for the period 1989-1993, which was approved by
Parliament in December 1988 along with the 1989 budget, has the following
objectives: (I) the achievement of sustained economic growth, based on
the country's abundant natural resources; (ii) the creation of income-
earning employment opportunities particularly in rural areas; (iii) the
establishment of fiscal self-reliance; and (iv) the reduction of social
To achieve these medium-term development
and economic Inequalities. 	

 objectives, the Government is pursuing the following strategies: to
(i) improve its resource allocation by redirecting expenditure away from
consumption towards investment projects in the economic and infrastructure
sectors; (ii) improve the effectiveness of resource management;
(iii) increase the effectiveness and improve the management of external
assistance; and (iv) promote and support private sector investment
initiatives.

Along with the Development Plan and the 1989 budget, the
13.
Parliament also approved a Public Investment Program (PIP) for the years
1989-1993, which anticipates total expenditures of about K 1,557 million
($1,790 million) over the Plan period. In line with above-mentioned
development objectives, the bulk of investments will be in the
infrastructure sector, including those of the Commercial Statutory
Authorities (CSAs) in the fields of electricity, ports, post and
telecommunications, and national water supply and sewerage, with an amount
of K 675.9 million or about 43.4 per cent of total budget allocations.
Of the overall allocations for CSAs in the amount of K 223.6 million (or
14.35 per cent of total investments), about K 132.5 million have been
allocated for ELCOM, including provisions for the proposed Project.

The main objective of the Government's energy policy is to
14.
reduce dependence on imported fuels through the development of domestic,
preferably renewable, energy resources. However, despite the country's
vast hydropower and hydro-carbon resources, there are several practical
constraints in their development, due to the low domestic demand for
energy and the geographical fragmentation of the energy market with a
concentration of commercial energy consumption in isolated mining and
urban enclaves.

After having initially emphasized the role of unconventional
15.
energy resources like ethanol, wood pyrolysis, solar and photo voltaic
energy for transport, industrial and household purposes, and having to
some extent neglected the conventional energy resources, the Government,
since 1982, has placed more emphasis on the electricity subsector which
accounts for 44 per cent of total consumption of petroleum products, and
where options are at hand for the substitution of imported oil used in
power generation. Thus, the focus of the Government's energy strategy in
the power subsector has been reoriented towards developing the country's
vast hydropower resources for displacing imported oil. The Government's
present policy regarding indigenous gas resources is restricted to
developing them to displace imported oil-based generation in cases where
there is no export market for the product.

The scattered islands and the rugged, and In some places
16.
inaccessible, mountain ranges on the mainland eliminate any possibility
of full integration of ELCOM's power system. As a result, and despite the
country's vast and cheap hydropower resources, it is only possible to
develop medium and mini potential sites commensurate with the relatively
low demand levels in the isolated systems. The only exception is the
interconnection of the Ramu and Port Moresby systems, which provides an
opportunity for achieving economies of scale with regard to future

 5

hydropower projects on the mainland. A recent study indicates that such
an interconnection is unlikely to become economically viable until the
latter part of the 1990s.

In the past, poor reliability of power supply has resulted in
17.
extensive growth of diesel-based captive power generation. The Government
and ELCOM are therefore placing considerable emphasis on improving the
reliability of supply along with the development of hydropower resources,
so that those with uneconomic diesel-based captive power plants will
convert to utility supply. The tariff policy is also designed to
discourage such captive generation, and consumers of ELCOM with captive
power plants are thus required to pay 50 per cent standby charges.

18.
The vast majority of PNG's population (about 85 per cent) live
in rural areas. There are about 90 isolated villages ("C" centers) and
40 institutional centers (mainly hospitals) where electricity is supplied
by small diesel generating units, with the stations being administered by
the Government. These "C" centers are the only source of public
electricity supply in key centers in rural areas with commercial, health,
educational and administrative institutions serving the surrounding areas.
However, the cost of extending electricity supply to rural areas in most
parts of PNG is high due to the long distances, difficult terrain and low
load density. As ELCOM's investment decisions are based on strict
financial criteria (10 per cent FIRR and EIRR in real terms), its
operations are largely confined to urban centers. The Government, because
of resource constraints, has decided not to increase the number of "C"
centers and has requested ELCOM to study viable options for providing
electricity in rural areas. A recent study carried out by consultants
indicates that for such purpose it would be necessary to modify ELCOM's
urban-oriented technical standards for developing more cost-effective
designs for rural distribution. The recommendations of the consultants
as well as the financial and policy implications of undertaking a large-
scale rural electrification program are currently being reviewed by the
Government and ELCOM.

Since 1985, the Government has also been pursuing a "Diesel
19.
Power Displacement Program" for developing micro-hydropower sites to
displace diesel-based generation in "C" centers with a view to reducing
the supply costs and improving the quality of electricity supply. Under
the program, which was to be implemented over a five-year period with an
estimated cost of K 10 million, it was envisaged to develop 10 mIni-
hydroelectric schemes and two transmission line schemes, to prepare
feasibility studies for future sites and to provide for training.
However, because of the high development costs and low financial returns
the Government has been relying mainly on grant-financing of the program,
and so far only one site has been developed (with EEC funding), and two
more sites are expected to be completed in 1989.

In early 1989, the Government also initiated a "Rural Energy
20.
Development Program", whose main objectives are: to (I) introduce
domestic renewable energy sources to rural areas, viz, solar, wind and
biomass; (ii) further reduce dependence on imported fuels; and (iii) to

 6

meet the basic energy needs of rural communities through appropriate
technologies. Initially, it is intended to establish a nation wide data
base for the renewable energy resource potential, conduct a technical and
economic evaluation of previous and present renewable energy projects and,
depending on the availability of funds, to implement projects aimed at
providing for the basic energy needs of the rural coinnitinities.

C.	

Institutional Framework and Executing Agency

1.	

Department of Minerals and Energy

21. The Department of Minerals and Energy (DOME) is responsible for
the assessment and development of the country's mineral and energy
resources, the issuance and monitoring of mining and petroleum licenses,
the formulation of national energy policies and the implementation of
selected renewable energy projects. Within DOME, the Energy Planning Unit
(EPU), established in 1978 to assist the Government in its efforts to
diversify the sources of energy, has the responsibility for energy
planning. So far, EPU has mainly provided advice on key energy projects,
initiated the compilation and collection of sector-related data, and
promoted the use of renewable energy resources.

2.	

The PNG Electricity Commission (ELCOM)

22.
Established under the PNG Electricity Commission Act of 1961,
ELCOM became a Commercial Statutory Authority (CSA) in October 1983.
Under the policy framework established by the Government for CSAs, ELCOM
is responsible for the planning, construction, operation an maintenance
of public electricity supply throughout the country, as well as for the
efficient management of its power supply facilities, its investments, and
its borrowings directly or through the Government from domestic and
international capital markets. Regarding the structure and level of its
tariffs, ELCOM, as a CSA, is subject to the approval by the Government's
Price Controller, who is the Secretary of the Department of Finance and
Planning (DOFP).

23.
Although responsibility for ELCOM is vested in the Minister for
Minerals and Energy, government control and supervision is exercised
primarily through ELCOM's Board of Commissioners. The Board consists of
the Secretary of DOME (as Chairman), one member each of the DOFP and the
Department of Lands and Physical Planning (DOLPP), and four members
representing private enterprises. Headed by a General Manager, ELCOM's
organizational structure consists of four main departments, viz.
Administration, Commercial, Operations and Engineering, and three offices
(provincial management and two special project offices). A Corporate
Secretary is in charge of safety, internal audit, public relations and the
Boards administration units. The General. Manager, the Deputy General
Manager, the four Department Heads, and the Corporate Secretary constitute
the top management of ELCOM, being responsible for the Implementation of
the policy directives and all operational matters. The area managers In
each of the 26 urban centers are also responsible for the operation and
maintenance of the electricity generation units at the Government centers

 7

("C" centers) in their respective areas. ELCOM's organization structure
is considered adequate for Its current and future functional requirements.

During the 1980s, ELCOM made significant efforts to improve its
24.
organizational, structure, its staff's technical skills in power system
operations and maintenance, and financial and Information systems. In
these efforts ELCOM was assisted, among others, through a Bank financed
technical assistance for the enhancement of ELCOM's accounting, financial
and management information systems and procedures !/, and through a human
resources development project financed by IBRD in conjunction with the
Yonki Hydroelectric Project loan. Since mid-1980s, ELCOM has been
striving to rationalize its staffing, which resulted in the reduction of
its workforce by 17 per cent from 2,316  in 1984 to 1,928 in 1988. The
number of expatriate staff has been reduced from 136 in 1986 to 120 in
1988, with further reductions envisaged in line with the Government's
policy guidelines for the public service.

ELCOM has progressively computerized its commercial operations,
25.
and with the Bank's technical assistance for the institutional study (see
para. 24), completed its accounting and financial planning system in 1987,
which is now considered adequate and in conformity with modern power
utility procedures and practices and international accounting standards.
'ntil 1981 the external audit was performed by the Auditor General's
Office, and since then, due to staff constraints, by external auditors,
whose reports are reviewed and certified by the Auditor General. ELCOM
has so far complied with Bank's covenants regarding the timely submission
of its audited annual accounts to the Bank.

In January 1982, the Government had implemented regional cost-
26.
based tariffs, which closely followed the recommendations of a Bank-
financed tariff study. 2/ However, due to equity considerations and since
electricity sales in the higher cost diesel generation centers comprised
only 10 per cent of ELCOM's total sales, the Government subsequently
reintroduced a uniform national tariff. The present tariff structure is
considered to be generally satisfactory. ELCOM is required to inform the
Bank promptly of any proposed changes in its tariffs.

Since 1982, ELCOM's financial performance has been satisfactory,
27.
and its revenues from energy sales increased until 1987 at a rate of about
7 per cent per annum, mainly due to an annual increase of 5.3 per cent in
energy sales. The total operating expenses increased from K 35.7 million
in 1982 to K 46.0 million in 1987, representing likewise an annual
increase of 5.3 per cent, but still less than the average annual inflation
rate of 6 per cent over the period.

1/	

TA No. 559-PNG: Institutional Study of PNG Electricity Commission,
approved on 5 December 1983 in the amount of $250,000.

2/ TA No. 307-PNG: Electricity Tariff Review, approved on 27 September

1979 in the amount of $70,000.

 8

Under the Bank's (and IBRD's) existing loans, ELCOM agreed to
28.
set its tariffs so as to achieve a 10 per cent rate of return (ROR) on
historically valued net fixed assets in operation, as well as to maintain
a debt-service ratio (DSR) of at least 1.5 times and a self-financing
ratio (SFR) of at least 30 per cent. Despite being subject, since 1983,
to a 35 per cent income tax, and paying dividends to the Government at a
rate of about 7 per cent on its equity capital since 1984, ELCOM has still
been able to comply with all of the Bank's financial loan covenants in the
past. However, in the absence of further Government equity infusion since
1985, ELCOM had to depend mainly on debt-financing for its capital
expansion, resulting in an increase of the ratio of total debt to equity
capital from 48:52 in 1982 to 58:42 as of end of 1987, which, however, is
still considered acceptable. Based on ELCOM's financial forecast for the
years 1989-1998, the debt to equity ratio is expected to decrease by the
end of the period to 41:59. During 1988-1998, ELCOM's profitability,
debt-service capability and capital structure are expected to be
maintained at satisfactory levels, and to enable ELCOM to comply with the
Bank's financial covenants, except for a slightly lower than covenanted
self-financing ratio in 1988 and 1989, mainly due to the higher than
anticipated level of expenditure for the Yonki Dam Project as a result of
change of design of the project.

ELCOM's current ten-year plan (1989-1998) envisages the addition
29.
of about 166 MW of generating capacity including 93 MW of hydropower
capacity - 60 MW at the Port Moresby hydropower project, 30 MW at the
Yonki Hydroelectric project (expected to be completed in 1991), and 3 MW
at the proposed Project. The ten-year plan anticipates total capital
expenditures of about K 413 million (In constant 1988 prices), with the
bulk of foreign exchange cost expected to be provided by multilateral
banks such as the Bank, IBRD and the European Investment Bank (EIB),
bilateral aid primarily from OECF, and commercial banks. Financing of
local currency cost is expected to come mainly from ELCOM's internal cash
resources.

To meet the substantial debt-service requirements and to provide
30.
adequate funds for the sizeable capital expansion program envisaged under
its current ten-year plan, ELCON needs to increase its tariffs at about
6.0 per cent per annum. However, a more realistic assessment of future
tariff increases is expected to be available on completion of the Power
System Planning Study to be shortly undertaken by ELCOM (see para. 31).

Recent developments have significantly altered the basic
31.
planning assumptions on which ELCOM's present ten-year plan is based.
These include: (i) the programs recently initiated by the Government for
accelerated development of non-mineral industries, fisheries and agro-
based industries, dispersal of economic growth centers, and for increased
assistance to the private sector, all of which will have a significant
impact on the load growth; (ii) the actual and potential discoveries of
on-shore and off-shore oil and gas reserves; and (iii) the lower-than-
anticipated prices of imported oil in recent years. Based on these
developments there is an urgent need for a systematic planning study for
all ELCOM systems with updated data so that future investments in system

 9

expansion will be optimized. This will be addressed by a recently
approved Bank technical assistance 1/, which also provides for the further
upgrading of ELCOM's institutional capabilities in system planning through
training and technology transfers.

D.	

External Assistance for the Energy Sector

As of 31 March 1989, PNG has received external assistance for
32.
the energy sector totalling about $255.7 million, comprising about $242.3
million in loans and about $13.4  In grants. The loans focussed primarily
on the development of ELCOM's hydropower projects, with nearly 50 per cent
(about $126.2 million) having been provided for the Yonki Hydroelectric
Project. Grants were provided mainly for feasibility studies, non-
conventional energy resources, advisory technical assistance projects and
equipment. Multilateral assistance was provided by IBRD ($63.5 million),
the Bank ($35.9 million) and EIB/EEC ($21.0 million). Among bilateral
donors Japan (OECF) ranks first with about $113.0 million, followed by the
Commonwealth Development Corporation (CDC) with $13.0 million, Norway
($7.75 million), Australia ($ 1 . 1 7 million) and New Zealand ($0.25
million). Details of the external assistance are set out in Appendix 1.

II. BANK OPERATIONS IN PAPUA NEW GUINEA

A Board Information Paper providing general information on
33.
overall Bank Operations in PNG was circulated to the Board of Directors
in June 1989 (see para. 3).

A.	

Bank's Operational Strategy

The primary development objective of the Government is to
34.
promote income growth and employment generation with the strengthening
and bro&dening of domestic resource-based production capacities (see para.
12). This translates in PNG into a continuing emphasis on agriculture,
where the bulk of economic activities takes place. In view of this, and
in line with Bank's "lead role" in the sector, the Bank will give greater
attention to broadening the agricultural base through diversification and
intensification in the treecrops and foodcrops subsectors and to the
development of the livestock, forestry and fisheries subsectors. While
the manufacturing sector is still at a early stage of development, the
Bank will, to the extent possible, assist in the country's
industrialization process, focussing on agro-industries and on small-and
medium-scale enterprises, and Indirectly assist private sector industrial
projects through the development of industrial estates. In social
infrastructure, the Bank will continue its prominent role in the health
subsector and will also continue its involvement in the urban water supply
and sewerage subsectors to improve the living conditions of the increasing
urban population of the country. Since substantial assistance from other

1/	

TA No. 1131-PNG:	
February 1989 in the amount of $515,000.

Power System Planning Study, approved on 27

 10

donors is available for the education subsector, mostly on highly
concessional terms, the Bank's role in this area will be only
complementary, likewise in the urban infrastructure and housing
subsectors.

Regarding the development of physical infrastructure, a critical
35.
requirement for the socio-economic integration of the country, the Bank
has, in the past, played an important role In the power, roads, and ports
subsectors through sector studies, Investment projects and related
institutional strengthening. Within the sector, about 12 per cent of
Bank's total lending to the country and about 17 per cent of its technical
assistance have been provided to the power subsector (see para. 36). In
line with Government's medium-term Investment program for the subsector
(see para. 13), and in accordance with Its energy policy, which aims to
harness the energy potential of the country and provide adequate and
reliable power supply to meet the country's development needs, the Bank
will continue its involvement in the subsector on a selective basis, among
others through the proposed Project. Other areas of Bank assistance
include manpower development, institutional support and contributing to
increasing the country's absorptive capacity.

B.	

Bank Assistance to the Power Subsector

Since 1977, the Bank has provided four loans totalling $34.6
36.
million for the power subsector in PNG. Three of the loans were for
hydropower projects, one of which (the Upper Warangoi Hydropower Project
(Loan Nos. 414/415 (SF)-PNG)), was co-financed by OECF ($14.5 million) and
Norway ($7.75 million). In addition, technical assistance has been
provided for six projects with a total amount of $1.308 million,
comprising two PPTAs and four AOTAs, the latter focussing mainly on power
planning, tariffs and institutional strengthening (for details see
Appendix 2).

The implementation of the Upper Warangoi Hydropower Project, the
37.
only project so far completed and post-evaluated, has been satisfactory.
The post-evaluation of the project concluded that the project had been
successfully completed with only a minor delay and a modest cost overrun.
Follow-up action was recommended in the PPAR to increase the energy sales
by providing special tariffs to potential industrial consumers and
improving the power supply reliability. In line with these
recommendations, ELCOM reintroduced industrial tariffs which had been
suspended in 1981, and the proposed Project will contribute to Improving
supply reliability.

Delays, however, were experienced in the implementation of the
38.
Provincial Mini-Hydropower Project (Loan No. 318-PNG) and the Ramu Grid
Reinforcement Project (Loan No. 805-PNG). Of the four schemes originally
comprising the Provincial Mini-Hydropower Project two were delayed due to
the unavailability of suitable local construction plant and equipment,
and were commissioned only in 1981 and 1982, respectIvely. Because of the
resulting cost overrun, the viability of the remaining two schemes was re-
evaluated by ELCOM, and one of the schemes was cancelled, whereas

 11

implementation of the remaining one resumed in 1986, with completion now
envisaged for September 1989. Due to frequent changes in the decision on
the source of power supply for the Porgera mining complex, the Ramu Grid
Reinforcement Project was also delayed. However, the implementation of
the Project was resumed in May 1988, when the Porgera power supply was
finalized. The contract for the major project component, the Ramu-Goroka-
Mt. Hagen 132 kV transmission line, has since been awarded and the line
is now scheduled to be completed in mid-1991.

Some of the earlier delays were caused by external factors
39.	
beyond the control of ELCOM. However, the proposed Project is well
prepared, with the tender documents for civil and electro-mechanical works
proposed to be finalized and issued in July 1989, subject to Board
approval of the proposed Project (see para. 51). Also, the land
acquisition process, in other projects frequently the cause for prolonged
delays, is scheduled to be completed in mid-1989 (see para. 49). Thus,
the Implementation delays which occurred in earlier Bank-financed power
projects in the country, are not expected with the proposed Project.

III. THE PROJECT

40.
in Papua New Guinea' (Report No. LAP:PNG-20079) is circulated herewith.

A report entitled "Appraisal of the Divune Hydropower Project

A.	

Project Objectives, Scope and Description

The main objectives of the proposed Project are to displace the
41.
high-cost imported diesel-based power generation in Popondetta (Oro-
Province) with lower-cost indigenous, renewable and reliable hydropower
and to extend the power supply facilities to other important load centers
in the area. Popondetta is the administrative and commercial center of
the province, which has a total population of about 97,200 people. Of
this, about 17,190 are living in the Popondetta district, including 8,000
in the township. The economy of the district is primarily based on
agriculture and timber, with major crops being cocoa, coconut and oil
palm, and minor crops including coffee, cardamom and chillies. Efforts
are being made by the Government to broaden the economic base of the area
by encouraging cattle farming in the district, which has also some agro-
and timber based industrial enterprises like saw-mills, agro-processing
plants etc.

At present, Popondetta is provided with 24-hour power supply
42.
from ELCOM's diesel power station with a total installed capacity of
1,780 kW. However, the units are old and have an aggregate site rating
of only 1,400 kW. Some smaller settlements in the district have also
access to limited power supply through small diesel units, and, in
addition, some of the larger plantations and industries have their own
captive power plants. Based on two consultant studies, carried out in
1984 and 1988, the development of the Divune (Luwini) creek with a 3 MW
hydropower station, is considered to be the least cost power supply option
for the Popondetta area. The design and detailed engineering for the

 proposed Project were completed in February 1989.

12

43. The proposed Project will have the following components:
(1) the construction of a hydropower station with two units of 1.5 MW each
and associated civil works; (ii) the construction of about 85 km of 22 kV
lines with associated step-down transformer substations for transmitting
the hydropower to the various load centers in the Project area; and
(iii) consulting services for engineering assistance during the
construction phase.

B.	

Project Cost and Financing Plan

44. The total cost of the Project is estimated at $12.29 million,
of which $8.43 million (69 per cent) is the foreign exchange cost,
including $1.0 million for interest and other charges during construction
(IDC) on the Bank loan. The local currency cost is estimated at $3.86
million (31 per cent), including taxes and duties. These cost estimates
are based on early 1989 prices and include appropriate provisions for
physical and price contingencies.

45. It is proposed that the Bank provides a loan of $8.43 million,
representing about 69 per cent of total Project cost, which will finance
the entire foreign exchange cost of the Project including IDC on the Bank
loan. The local currency cost of about $3.86 million equivalent will be
met out of ELCOM's own resources. The proposed Bank loan will be from
the Bank's ordinary capital resources (OCR), with interest to be
determined in accordance with the Bank's pool-based variable lending rate,
and a commitment charge of 0.75 per cent per annum in accordance with the
Bank's current policy. The loan would have a repayment period of twenty
years, including a grace period of three years. The Borrower would be the
Independent State of Papua New Guinea. The Borrower would relend the
proceeds of the loan to ELCOM as the Executing Agency under a subsidiary
loan agreement with a relending rate set at the standard rate applicable
to CSAs in PNG (currently 10.35 per cent per annum), but not less than the
OCR rate of the Bank at the time of the loan approval by the Bank. 1/ The
Borrower would bear the foreign exchange risk. These terms and conditions
are deemed to be appropriate, taking into consideration the economic life
of the Project and its implementation period.

C.	

Project Implementation

1.	

The Executing Agency

46.	
The Executing Agency for the proposed Project will be ELCOM (see
paras. 22 to 31). ELCOM has substantial experience in implementing
similar projects financed by multilateral and bilateral donors, including
those of the Bank (see paras. 32 and 36), and is considered suitable to
implement the proposed Project. 	
ELCOM will designate an engineer

1/	

The same re-lending conditions applied for Loan No. 805-PNG: Ramu
Grid Reinforcement Project, approved in November 1986.

 13

acceptable to the Bank as Project Manager for providing coordination
between ELCOM, the consultants and contractors. The Project Manager will
be assisted by adequate and qualified staff. ELCON will also be
responsible for construction supervision and contract management.

2.	

Consulting Services

47.	
It is estimated that about two man-months of consulting services
would be required for engineering assistance during the construction phase
of the Project. It is proposed that in the interest of timely and
economic Project implementation and in accordance with the Bank's
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants, the consultant who was responsible
for the final feasbility studies and detailed engineering of the Project
be retained for providing these services.

3.	

Procurement

48. Procurement of goods and services to be financed from the
proceeds of the proposed Bank loan will be carried out by ELCOM in
accordance with the Bank's Guidelines for Procurement. For the civil
works and the electro-mechanical works components of the Project,
international competitive bidding (ICB) procedures will be adopted.
Because of the estimated small contract values, international shopping
(IS) procedures will be applied for the transmission component. For this
purpose, four packages for procurement have been identified, namely:
(1) conductors and accessories; (ii) 22 kV transformers; (iii) poles; and
(iv) electrical hardware including insulators. While the construction of
the civil works and the electro-mechanical works are proposed to be
undertaken by contractors, with the latter on supply-and-erect basis, the
22 kV system is proposed to be constructed by ELCOM, which has developed
the requisite technical expertise for such undertaking.

4.	

Land Acquisition and Right-of-Way

The land survey for the proposed Project has already been
49.	
completed and the land owners identified. In view of the expected
benefits the land owner's response to the Project is reportedly favorable,
with the DLOPP currently assessing the appropriate compensation amount.
Although the land acquisition process is presently envisaged to be
completed by August 1989, due to the importance of timely acquisition of
all lands, right over land and water and other property rights for
implementing the Project as per schedule, the completion of land
acquisition has been stipulated as a condition for the award of the first
contract for civil works.

5.	

Reports, Accounts and Audit

50. ELCON will maintain separate accounts for all goods and services
financed from the proceeds of the Bank loan and will have these accounts
audited annually by its external auditors. The audited accounts and the
related financial statements, after appropriate review and certification
by the Auditor General's Office, will be submitted to the Bank, in the

 14

English language, not later than nine months after the end of the
respective fiscal year. ELCOM will also give the Bank quarterly progress
reports on the execution of the Project, and will submit a project
completion report not later than three months after the completion of the
Project.

6.

Implementation Schedule

Subject to the approval of the proposed Project by the Bank, the
51.	
tender documents for the civil works and electro-mechanical works are
proposed to be finalized and issued in July 1989. The respective
contracts are scheduled to be awarded by January 1990 and the civil works
(including the construction of the access road) to be completed within two
years. The Project is expected to be commissioned in early 1992.

7.

Op eration and Maintenance

52.
ELCOM will be responsible for the appropriate operation and
maintenance (0&M) of the Project. ELCOM has considerable experience in
O&M of small and medium-sized hydropower plants and 22 kV systems, and
the electro-mechanical tender for the Project also provides for training
of selected ELCOM staff by the supplier in the specific skills required
for 0&M of the units supplied. With these additional inputs, ELCOM's
existing O&M organization and staffing is considered adequate for
operating and maintaining the power plant and the transmission system
covered under the Project.

D.	

Environmental Aspects

The catchment area of the proposed Project is uncultivated and
53.
is expected to remain so due to the steepness and ruggedness of the
terrain. The exuberant rain forest provides good protection to the soil
and no signs of soil erosion or excessive sedimentation have been found.
Since the Project is a run-of-the-river type not needing extensive civil
works or a dam, and the associated transmission system involves only the
construction of pole-mounted 22 kV lines routed along the existing roads,
the Project will not have any significant impact on the environment. The
Environmental Plan for the Project submitted by ELCOM has already been
approved by the Minister of Environment and Conservation.

F.	

Benefits and Justification

The proposed Project supports the Government's objective of
54.
displacing high-cost imported diesel-based power generation with low-cost,
indigenous, and renewable hydropower and to improve the supply reliability
in the Project area. The Project is designed as the least-cost power
generation option for meeting the existing and future power demand in
Popondetta and the adjacent load centers. The Project will directly
benefit about 17,000 people in Popondetta and nearby load centers and
indirectly benefit about 80,000 people in the Oro Province by stimulating
economic growth and providing the necessary infrastructure. The economic
(1) cost savings due to the
benefits from the Project comprise: 	

 15

displacement of existing diesel based power generation; (ii) revenue from
the sale of electricity to additional consumers; and (iii) consumer's
surplus in respect of (ii). The EIRR for the Project is estimated at 13.8
per cent, and the FIRR at about 12.7 per cent, which are considered
satisfactory given the nature of the Project.

F.	

Policy Issues and Related Matters

55. In view of the continuing dialogue between the Bank, the
Government and ELCOM on sector-related issues along with the
implementation of the previous Bank-financed loans and technical
assistance projects, there are no major policy issues regarding the
proposed Project. The Bank has impressed on ELCOM the need to reach as
soon as possible the covenanted self-financing ratio of 30 per cent, which
had been stipulated under the Ramu Grid Reinforcement Project (Loan No.
805-PNG) and is expected to be slightly lower in 1988 and 1989 due to the
higher than anticipated level of expenditure on the Yonki Dam Hydropower
Project (see para. 28).

G.	

Project Risks

56.	
No major technical or economic risks are foreseen regarding the
Project's physical components, all of which involve proven and
conventional technologies of relatively simple design. Although the
Project site lies close to the Owen Stanley fault and is therefore located
in a zone classified as being between medium and low risk, the Project
components have been designed for medium risk conditions so as to maximize
the ductility of the structures, minimize the damage and keep the Project
operational in the event of any major seismic disturbance. The adopted
technology is a proven one and poses no significant technical risk. There
is still a risk of possible delays in Project implementation due to delays
in land acquisition. However, although the land acquisition process is
presently anticipated to be completed by August 1989 (see para. 49), it
has been stipulated that no contracts will be awarded until the process
is completed, thereby minimizing any impact such delay might have on the
economic and financial viability of the Project. Since major additions
to the load are envisaged through the conversion of diesel-based captive
power generation to supply from ELCOM once the Project is completed, and
expanding economic activities in the Project area are expected in the
medium-term, any economic risks of energy sales remaining below the
present forecast are also minimal.

IV. LEGAL INSTRUMENTS AND AUTHORITY

57.	

Drafts of the following documents are circulated herewith:

(i) Loan Agreement (Ordinary Operations) between the Independent

State of Papua New Guinea and the Bank; and

(ii) Project Agreement between the Bank and the Papua New Guinea

Electricity Commission (ELCOM).

 16

58. The provision of the Bank's Ordinary Operations Loan Regulations
dated 1 July 1986 are incorporated in the draft Loan Agreement, subject
to the modifications set forth in Section 1.01 thereof.

59. The Independent State of Papua New Guinea is empowered under its
constitution and laws to borrow from the Bank. ELCOM is authorized to
enter into and to implement its obligations under the proposed Project
Agreement.

60.	
Articles of Agreement of the Bank.

I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the

V. RECOMMENDATION

61.	
Project as proposed.

The President has endorsed the involvement of the Bank in this

62. Acting in the absence of the President, under the provisions of
the last sentence of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of the
Bank, I recommend that the Board approve the proposed loan to the
Independent State of Papua New Guinea for the Divune Hydropower Project
in an amount of $8.43 million equivalent, with interest in accordance with
the Bank's pool-based variable lending rate system, and carrying such
other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those
set forth in the relevant draft agreements presented to the Board.

S. STANLEY KATZ
Vice President

8 June 1989
